												Mini Ninjas is quite a good game. I love the characters, enemies and combat system, (usually) and the game's voice actors do a pretty good job as well. It has quite an "open world" feel, whereas, it's not an open world, but you don't feel limited to a single path. The story is simple, you're a ninja and the evil samurai warlord is threatening to take over the world. You go out on a quest to defeat this warlord and save the ninjas who failed to do so before you. The game looks very nice in my opinion, and the music, while not anything amazing, does compliment it nicely. Combat system works good, you get a couple ninjas you can switch between, To be honest I only used like 3-4 of them, and that's because sometimes you must use a specific character. The bosses are basically: Run from boss until you're able to do a quicktime event. They're all quicktime events, so don't expect a whole lot of difficulty with them.But for me, I found this game to have some broken aspects/parts. On the "avalanche escape" sequence, It's incredibly hard to see, which is understandable, but I kept falling through cracks, or holes, and instead of dying, I'd be rolling/sliding until the avalanche eventually caught up with me. This was a VERY monotonous part of the game, and it really put a downer on the overall game. When you are in your hat on the water, it's quite soothing. but when you have to use your hat/boat to go through small waterways, it's incredibly slow and can be irritating.  This game is indeed a kids game, don't expect a big story, deep characters or a long playthrough, but I have to admit, the cutscenes between the Warlord and his captains are hilarious.This is a very good game for 10 euros, and I got it in a sale for 4, so I really recommend this game for players looking to burn off a couple hours without much challenge. I give it a fair 7/10, it's a cute game and it's worth the money.

												Steam is home to a lot of crap, and I do mean a lot.. But it also is home to a number of hidden gems that no one really talks about much.Mini Ninjas is one of those gems. A bit of an imperfect one, sure, but a gem nontheless. And like many hidden gems, it doesn't get a whole lot of attention. The game is kinda an action adventure game, with small elements of RPG and stealth. You play the role of a ninja named Hiro, who is tasked with finding all his lost friends and saving the world while he is at it. A lot of pressure, I know, but then you are a ninja with the power to control the elements, so it shouldn't be too hard (Which kinda is a problem for the game, I'll explain later)Being that you play the role of a ninja, stealth is a tool you'll be making a lot of use out of. As some might indicate, however, the stealth aspect of the game isn't really all that advanced, and oftentimes isn't used to avoid fights so much as it is to get the first strike in any given fight (or outright kill everyone in a patrol before they even have time to react). While it is possible to avoid fights, you won't want to in the early game, because you need to fight to gain XP and level up. Otherwise, the road ahead will be awfully harsh to those who don't kick enough butt. While quietly avoiding fights isn't encouraged (At least in the early game), the stealth system does indeed work very well, and in the late game, where  by then you are already maxed out, it becomes much more viable.When the time comes to fight, however, it is a mixed bag. Combat is simple, with a few basic attacks, a block breaker, and even a super move that can cause all sorts of pain for those unlucky to be the target of it. You also have a selection of items that can make fights go more smoothly, such as pepper bombs and potions that make arrows bounce off your face. However, the problem is that it IS simple, even to the point of simply mashing the two buttons until everyone is dead before moving on to the next fight. I myself don't mind it, but those seeking a deeper combat system might not enjoy the game as much.Sure, as you progress through the game you'll unlock more ninjas to fight with, each having their own style (Such as the fat ninja's brute force hammer skills that can make fighting larger enemies blindingly easy, or the archer ninja's ranged combat skills). However, I never really did bother to use any of them besides the ninja you start with. In DK 64, the devs made it so that you had to use all the Kongs in order to beat the game, so you couldn't just march through the whole game with Donkey Kong the whole time. Not so much here, where you can get through the entire game without changing ninjas ONCE. Maybe on hard mode, you would have to swap out ninjas more often, but on normal mode it is rather pointless for the most part, and in some cases even more fun, since fighting larger enemies feels more satisfying when you have to put up a real fight to take them down, rather than swapping over to fat ninja and just wailing on them, stun locking them to death. And even moreso, the starter ninja is the only one who can use magic, and as you progress through the game, you'll learn how important magic is.So, the combat is ok at best, the whole 6 ninja team gimmic is iffy when you can go through the whole game with the main star of the game just fine (and possibly makes the adventure so much more interesting and challenging), and stealth early on, while it does play a considerable role in the game, is mostly used for ambushing more than avoiding conflict altogether. And yet... I love this game.Maybe it is because it reminds me of the glory days, back when we had games like Banjo & Kazooie 1 & 2, Conker's Bad Fur Day, Jak and Daxter... You know those kind of games? The ones where you feel like you are on a real adventure throughout an interesting, if sometimes even strange, world waiting to be explored. You start out in your humble village, venturing out chapter after chapter on your way to the big bad guy himself, taking out his generals and anyone else who dares to get in your way, while at the same time taking a moment to explore the area for goodies and new spells to unlock. It helps that the world and the music that fills it is quite appealing, making the journey all the more enjoyable. That, and it is around 9-10 hours on my first playthrough, so you get your money's worth for sure. Gotta love a game that keeps you busy for a nice long while.As much as I'd like to yammer on and on, I'd like to wrap it up as a game that, while the gem is a bit cloudy, it is a gem nontheless, and a shame that it isn't more popular, let alone given a respected sequel (instead getting spinoffs on the Kinect and a Ipad runner.. Yeah, kinda a sad fate for the ninjas if you ask me).

												Mini Ninjas is an extremely unnoticed game, and I believe it won't let you down. The setting is simple: A samurai warlord created an army by turning adorable animals into little warriors with his evil magic. The protagonists' mission is to defeat him and restore the balance of nature. Each character has his/ her unique abilities and special moves. Plus there are a lot of Kuji spells, potions and weapons so you can develop your own tactics to fight off the enemies. Besides, there are various scenes which are stunning and refreshing. You can fish, look for herbs and new Kuji spells while exploring. The boss fights are incredibly fun as they have different weaknesses and you have to find out the specific tricks yourself to defeat them. The soundtracks composed by Japanese traditional instruments work flawlessly and suit the gameplay very well. The rhythmic Taiko Drumming adds so much tension. However, the length of this game might be too short for those who have no interest in exploring and collecting stuff. The game might not work well in newer systems (because this is a rather old game)To conclude, Mini Ninjas provided me an unforgettable gaming experience. I highly recommend this game to anyone who likes relaxing gameplay and imaginative stories.9/10

												Writing this for the “I Thought This Game Was Cool Before It Won An Award” Award:This title didn’t have a huge marketing machine behind it, but just about anyone that finds it ends up loving it. Then you tell your friends about it. And they love it. And now that little game that could is my nomnation to win an award… but always remember: you totally found it first.This game when it was released years ago on the Xbox 360 was an absolute gem!!!  Not too hard, not rediculously easy, and just had all the ingredients that made this game fun to play!  Remember...when games were less demanding (even in achievements) and just FUN?  This game hails from the days of Conker and Banjo Kazooie like many other reviewers can attest but for some reason Mini Ninjas lacked the marketing and PR those games received.  It is a platformer involving stealth but the game is mechanically forgivable and although challenges do exist, it is not overly repetitive, too long in gameplay, or frustrating to complete.  The music and graphics also make this game an awesome couch game relax to and  play.  The current price it is an absolute steal and it is often in many Steam Sales over the holidays.  Back in my concole days - It was so good I gave it to my friend who had a son at the time.  Then I would watch father and son (and ocassionally mom) play this little treasure together family bonding and beating stages and handing the controller to one another as the game progressed.  The son was 5 but he loved this game, and it often served as good entertainment for the son in an opposite room while the parents, other friends, and I would hang out.  This little game is still fun. Even today, Mini Ninjas is just a precious zen-like little game that has this surprising ability to become cherished in the minds and hearts of anyone that takes the time to play it.  It is just that good!

content:
Posted: August 19, 2014
												Mini Ninjas feels like a throwback to the PSX and N64 era, with games like Banjo Kazooei, Super Mario 64, Medievil and so on.It's a 3D Action Platformer, designed to have open levels, with collectibles spread all over.While the game's description (on this page) is not entirely wrong, it can be deceiving. First off, if you're looking for a Stealth game, do not get this one. While stealth is possible, it's neither encouraged by the level design, nor very useful.The enemies are not designed to be approach silently, nor do the rooms have several possible entries and exits. It's not that type of game.It's more of a game designed for children, with a very lighthearted story, levels and Boss fights. Which isn't necessarly a bad thing.Let's talk about presentation first.Despite being a game from 2009, it's looks great!The cartoony style fits well with the game's vibe, and everything looks very clean and smooth. No complaints here whatsoever, except for the background's resolution. For some reason, their resolution is noticeable lower, and feels weird to look at. But it's a minor complaint!It achieves the japanese looks very well, and uses simplicity to its advantage.The music is also really good, and complements the theme perfectly. It's not something that will be stuck in your head or anything, though. It's "merely" textural music, that adds a lot to the atmosphere and feels quite relaxing.During the more action-driven sections, the Taiko drums will also come in for a decent adrenaline rush. Overall, pretty good!One issue, though. Sometimes, the sound would start glitching for no apparent reason, making the game sound like System Shock instead of a ninja/samurai-themed game. I don't know what caused it, but just take that in mind.So far, so good! Why am I not recommending this game, then? Well, the level design and game mechanics don't fit very well together, unfortunately, which leads to an experience that gets repetitive very quickly.First off, the combat is very button mash-y. You have a normal hit, and a heavier hit, to stun blocking opponents. You can also run and jump. There are very few possible combos with these attacks, as can be imagined, which makes every fight be very much the same. You'll also unlock spells and other ninjas throughout your journey, as well as potions.The different ninjas are a great idea, but their execution is very flawed. Each ninja has a different special ability, and weapon. These can differ in range, speed, damage, etc. There's a ninja with a big hammer, one with claws, one with a spear, a bow, etc. And this could have been used very effectively! But it's not. Why? Mainly, because the appropriate situations and placed right when you get said character. And you can use them there pretty well. But throughout the rest of the game, their usefulness is very limited, and you're better off just using the normal ninja. Spells are useful, and more fun to use on large groups of opponents, but very rarely are necessary. Only the basic ninja is able to use them as well, which further limits the other ones. (You can switch between them at will, but it's still not worth the hassle).The potions are also a big flaw in the game, in my opinion. With the exception of Health potions, you have absolutely no reason to use them! They're not useful, nor necessary at any point in the game. To that, add that you'll have to use them from the menu, which means pausing the game and looking for the right one. It simply breaks the pacing, without a benefit. You can use keybindings for some potions, but those will most likely be in use for the spells already.It could have been a great addition, but there are no situations that ask for the use of these potions, so it's just a game mechanic and is left unused throughout. A waste of space, sorry to say.You can either get these by finding them in the levels, buying them from vendors, or crafting them with plants that you'll gather. So, now that the main mechanics are out of the way, let's talk about level design.There are 22 levels, 5 of which are Boss Fights. In each of them, there are 5 things to look out for: Spells, Plants, Coins, Statues, and Caged Animals. Aside from reaching the end of each level, you may want to collect these items.This leads to levels being very open, with these items spread throughout. Unfortunately, unlike, say, Super Mario 64, none of the levels was very interesting. In Mario, every level had a lot of different content, with different areas, character, challenging platforming sections, racing, etc. etc. Every single level was crafted carefuly.In Mini Ninjas, the levels are mostly bland. The items seem "hidden" randomly, transforming exploration into tedious walking. Besides, there doesn't really seem to be any reward by collecting these. While you can use the plants for crafting, and coins to buy potions/tools, these are never really useful, so, once again, it's wasted space.The same goes with the caged animals, which you can free for kindness alone, without any reward.While some levels to have different sections, the game drags for too long, starting about halfway through it. There are river rapids and an avalanche sections, in which you'll have to dodge rocks and trees at a high speed, but aside from those, all the levels play very similarly. (They do look differently, though, so that's good. There are mountains, snow, rice plantations, etc. etc. decent variety)Enemy variety is also questionable. Some enemies require somewhat different approaches, but not something enough to provide challenge. I've played it on Hard Mode, and you can certainly steamroll through the whole thing without much of a problem. This, once again, leads to a not very interesting game.Finally, let's talk about the Boss fights.The last fight was great! You had to use the different spells at your disposal to beat him, which took a couple of tries to get the strategy. The other ones, unfortunately, were just a question of baiting them, followed by a QTE section.You would observe their behaviour, until you got what to do to "unlock" the QTE. And then just to the same thing 3 times and you're done. It's a shame. Boss fights can usually be really interesting and different, but this game didn't seem to seize that opportunity very well.I've written enough.While I feel that Mini Ninja's heart is on the right place, its execution leaves a lot to be desired. It could have been a very fun game if it had used all its mechanics appropriately, or simply making a more condensed experience.Since it doesn't, I can't recommend this game at all. Wait for A Hat in Time, perhaps, if you're itching for this kind of gameplay!

												This game should be pulled for misadvertising, because if you think a game solely about Ninja would contain stealth, then you'd be wrong. Sure, there are stealth mechanics, sure, some areas give you paths to sneak past enemies, but if you want to rescue animals and gain XP, the only way you'll do that is by charging in and killing everything you see. You in fact lose out if you stealth.This game is about as barebones as it gets. Despite being a linier game split into levels, the end of each level tell you how many collectables you managed to snag on your way there. This includes: freed animals, flowers, Jinzo statues, spell scrolls, and money. "Great", you might think, "Lots of replayability!" Well, you'd be wrong. Freeing animals gives you XP, collecting plants gives you ingredients with which to craft potions (which I have yet to need), scrolls give you new spells, and the statues? Well, they're purely collectables - all of which, as far as I can tell, have absolutely no reward for collecting them all. There are no achevements, either on Steam or in-game, and aside from your base stats which are improved automatically when you level-up, there isn't anything they could offer in the way of a reward anyway. And yes, you read that correctly: money is a commodity. It's that useless.Mini Ninjas is an empty, soulless (albeit cute) journey down a long woodland-themed corridoor, with no real incentive to stray off the beaten path besides completionism. Fighting is just mashing 'attack', with special attacks or spells that one-hit-kill. The only reason you'd need to switch characters is to kill the heavy enemy (which is only easily killed by your heavy ninja) or cast spells, which only the default character can. The English voice-acting also seems to be have been assigned exclusively to one guy.So what's good? Well, the art-style is lovely. The mixture of ambient Japanese dialogue and English cutscene dialogue is nice. You can control animals, which is oddly rare in games... And that's about it.CONCLUSION: It pains me to say this about anything in the Ninja genre, but I recommend giving this title a miss, unless you're buying it for a child - the cartoon violence, quirky designs and easy controls make this a good entry-level romp through ancient Japanese culture.

												I initially wrote Mini Ninjas off as a kid's game. Along with that assumption came the idea that the gameplay mechanics would be simplistic, the levels would be basic and really guided, and that the game would be small, easy, and not worth bothering with.Along comes the Steam Winter Sale, and I figure that for a few dollars, I might as well check it out.This game completely blew me away!The first layer of gameplay complexity comes when you start rescuing your friends. You're enabled to switch between different characters with vastly different movement speed, attacks, and weaponry at the click of a button, even in the middle of combat. This opens up a whole new world of strategy as you can change your whole attack set in an instant.To further the depth, the game features a rudimentary crafting system. By finding various plants, you're able to craft potions which help you in your quest. They range from the basic health potion to the very useful Flame Oil (which makes your sword on fire).On top of the various potions, there are also purchaseable/scavengeable Ninja tools. These range from Shuriken and caltrops to various types of bombs. You even have a fishing rod you can use to fish for food/health.Finally, you have various Kuji Magic spells you can employ. These are very powerful and will come in handy constantly.You also have a hat, which acts as a basic shield to block incoming arrows. You also use it as a boat on water, and a sled on snow. There are a good amount of levels to explore, and exploration is encouraged as you need to explore to find all the Kuji magic spells and plants you need to craft your potions.The music and sound design is stellar. The world is very alive feeling, and is populated with believable sounds which form a detailed soundscape.Graphics are also wonderful, mixing careful detail with a very abstract painterly/paper style of art.The only issue I had was instability. That is easily fixed by finding and installing the OpenAL 2.1.0.0 runtimes. All of the earlier ones caused constant crashing on my computer.TLDR: Great game, way more depth than one would assume.

												Have you seen those screenshots? This game is PRETTY. Designed to a tee and brimming with charm and character, every area is a visual treat and full of areas to explore as well as a beaten track. There's some collectables and hidden areas everywhere, and with the help of the local (and adorable) fauna, you can sniff out the neat sights. Enemy design is also helped by wonderful, wonderful voice acting, and excellent characterisation of what ultimately are faceless goons and mooks. The enemy commanders are so at odds with what you might expect from a distance, and it's a lot of fun every time you get to engage one alone.The mechanics are a little odd when you think about it. On the face of it, the combat is pretty shallow. You've got an attack, a guard-breaker/stun, a block, and a dodge roll. It's simple, hit things, if they start blocking, stun, if they start hitting, block or dodge. There's not a lot of nuance and it's very forgiving, especially for the main combat system. But then again, the actual grit of the system is a finely-tuned machine. Strikes work on actual physical contact rather than wide hitboxes, so it's entirely possible to say, dodge a spear thrust just by moving to the side, or knock arrows out of the air with good timing. You'd be surprised what you can do with the simple tools offered, which are healthily supplanted by a vast array of ninja tools, bombs and potions, as well as character-specific special moves.Once you start unlocking other ninjas, you'll find things start getting very interesting indeed. They all have their unique niche, be it crowd clearing, ranged attacking, going fast, heavy damage, whatever. You'll find yourself flipping between them with impunity, often using all of them within one conflict. They do overlap though, so often it comes down to favourites, but that's okay too because they're all great. The specials all have their own uses, but again, you'll find yourself playing favourites depending on your usual style.It's not a kid's game, but it is a kid-friendly game. It's not like, stupidly easy, but it's not punishingly hard either. As an example, your health doesn't regenerate, but in any given area there'll be several ways to heal, if you look around. You can catch fish, brew/find/loot/buy potions, search for food on trees and in bushes, and a number of items have healing side-effects. There's a lot of stuff to do in here, and it could be overwhelming, but everything in the game is approached with such... just, here's a bunch of stuff, go. There's no point at which you're forced to brew potions, nor is there a forced catching fish segment. Those things are just there if you want to do them, and that's great.I think one of the key ideas here is options. You've got a handful of characters, a couple dozen spells and items, a place to get to and enemies between you and it. After that, it's all up to you. Wanna sneak around the grass and pick off the sentries? Fine! What about assaulting with explosives and keeping your distance? Sure! Simply run in and start smashing things, chugging health potions as needed? Go for it! There's a million different ways to play every encounter, and all of them are fun. The ease on the eyes doesn't hurt it either, and it's always nice to come across the next area and gasp a little at how pretty it is.+A wonderful, pretty journeyCharming as hellOptions galorePlenty of length-Avalanche (Protip: Sprint)Would you like to spend a nice time on a beautiful adventure filled with cute characters and forgiving but fun combat? Pull the trigger.

												Mini Ninjas is a great game if you like simple exploration games that pose little challenge. However, it has flaws.I recommend Mini Ninjas to anyone who enjoys Zelda games or basic action games. The idea in Mini Ninjas is that you are a the final ninja in a town who is sent to do two things: rescue 5 other lost ninjas and defeat the evil samurai that has brought evil to the land. The villain has turned many of the forest animals into evil samurais; these samurais serve as your primary enemies in this game.For the vast majority of the game, you will be running and fighting through fairly open exploration levels. I say "fairly" open level because while they give the initial appearance of being quite large, this is pretty much an illusion. The levels are mostly quite linear and I do not believe I ever was lost about where to go. While that is nice, I do wish the game relied on a more typical Zelda-style open world instead of using actual levels. Yes, this game actually runs you through levels, with the primary purpose of the levels being to limit you to the current area/region you are in. Because of this, you only have one way to go back and collect the items you missed. Replay the level. This is not a good feature of this game because it comes with several kinds of items to collect(statues, freeing animals, finding plants to use, etc.). I enjoy finding items. I do not enjoy having to replay 45 minutes of gameplay because I missed one item. I will also add that you get absolutely nothing for collecting all of an item on a level. If you find every single Jizo Statue(one of the itesm) on a level, you get nothing. Zippo. Odd.One of the really neat ideas in this game is that you are a ninja who possesses a few unique  ninja powers. You can use stealth to sneak up on enemies and sneak-kill them or you can use a variety of spells to attack. You can even use ninja items like smoke bombs and shurikens to either distract or damage them. However, these unique ninja skills end up exposing a major design flaw in the game. If you don't kill the enemies, you do not get their experience, which you need to upgrade your character and grow stronger and more resilient. The game should have rewarded the player for being a sneaky ninja. It doesn't.Additionally, as you rescue your fellow ninjas, you get to swap between them and use their powers. Unfortunately, their powers are almost entirely useless and none of them can use magic. Therefore, despite rescuing 5 ninjas throughout the game you end up relying on your initial ninja for 95% of the game. 2 of the new ninjas we rescued remained entirely unused because they offered nothing to help me through the game. Disappointing.Well, I've gone and listed some major flaws in the game, yet I am still recommending it. Why? It's actually quite a bit of fun and actually plays like a first game in what would have eventually become a great series. All the flaws I've listed above could have been repaired in the sequels. Despite having weaknesses, I had a blast playing through most of this game. It helps greatly that this is the easiest game I've played in many years. Sometimes you want a challenge, but in a game like this, it actually helped that it was easy. It was very much a game that kids could play; even when you kill enemies in this game, they return to animal form instead of dying. I had a grin on my face a lot of times while playing this game because it has a great sense of whimsy, wonderful art direction, lovely music, and smooth enough gameplay. Despite critiquing it, it was a lot of fun. Let me end by focusing entirely on the positive. While majorly flawed, the game saves itself with its incredible charm and bubbly personality. Combine that with little to no challenge and you have a lovely family-friendly game. I still enjoyed collecting items despite there being no purpose and I even liked fighting the enemies even though there was little skill involved. The game took me 11 hours to beat, though You could reduce that time by 25% if you don't bother to run around and take it all in. This game provided a very nice experience and was well worth the 11 hours I put into it. Had the game been a 25+ hour game, it would have severely hurt its rating, but for a pretty short game, it was nice. I will add one final minor beef, though. Where are the Steam Achievements? The game had a achievements on the Xbox 360 and PS3. Why were those not copied over to Steam? My final rating of the game:6/10 - Nice, but flawed. I wish there had been sequels that repaired some of the issues.
